;;日本首相石破茂周四在10月27日大选。照片：共同社;
;

;日本首相石破茂惨淡的公众支持率——几十年来日本新任领导人中的最低支持率——给执政党自民党(LDP)蒙上了一层阴影。 10 月 27 日大选，引发了领导层迅速面临挑战的担忧。

;

;分析人士警告称，糟糕的选举表现可能会让石破刚上任几周后成为跛脚鸭，迫使自民党严重依赖其初级联盟周四公布的时事新闻民意调查显示，公众对政府的支持率已骤降至 28%，这是自 2000 年以来的最低初始支持率。

;

;虽然这比前首相岸田文雄在 9 月份退出领导人竞选之前的 18.7% 稍好一些，但仍然低于被视为领导人“危险区”的关键 30% 门槛。

;

;岸田在任期开始时获得了超过 40% 的支持率，而他的前任菅义伟则在任期开始时获得了 51.2% 的支持率。

;
;;
;;周二，石破茂（左二）在福岛县的一次集会上与一名自民党候选人一起竞选。照片：EPA-EFE;
;
;

;“我预计自民党将失去绝对多数席位，但可能会继续与公明党一起执政，作为回报，公明党将能够推动其一些更多的政策东京国际基督教大学政治学教授史蒂芬·纳吉 (Stephen Nagy) 表示：“考虑到国家的分裂，自民党完全失去权力是“可能的”，尽管不太可能。未能在可获胜选区团结起来支持强有力候选人的反对党。

;

;石破茂被任命为党魁，很大程度上是因为他在近年来困扰自民党的一系列丑闻中清白的记录。然而，他一直努力与党的腐败问题保持距离。

;

;首先，统一教会丑闻暴露了宗教团体与党员之间令人不安的联系，影响了官方政策。 11 月爆发的行贿基金丑闻使情况更加复杂，揭露了总计约 6 亿日元（400 万美元）的伪造财务报告。四名内阁成员辞职，多人被捕，但尚未受到起诉。

;
;;
;;一名妇女举着一张标语牌，上面写着图像10 月 1 日，在东京议会大楼外的一次集会上，“击败石破”。照片：法新社;
;
;

;尽管竞选时承诺改革该党，但石破未能兑现，侵蚀了公众的信任。

;

;“人们不高兴，因为他很快就放弃了真正惩罚卷入行贿基金丑闻的人的计划，”纳吉说，并进一步指出，石破茂放弃了一项坚定的计划。十月初东盟峰会之前的北约与亚洲伙伴关系进一步损害了他的信誉。

;

;“当他退出这些问题时，情况看起来很糟糕，但随后他的第一次出国之行是参加东盟峰会和唯一的结果就是一份无聊的联合声明以及与[中国总理]李强的一次无关紧要的双边会晤。”纳吉说。

;

;除了石破茂的困境之外，秘书长森山宏领导的另一个自民党派系还面临着不负责任的指控。 -自石破刚上任以来，报告的政治资金超过320万日元。许多过去的基层成员也对他们的地方代表受到惩罚并且在竞选活动中得不到党的财政支持感到不满。

;

;目前，自民党在 465 个席位中拥有 247 个席位。即使没有公明党的 32 个席位，它也能在众议院占据多数席位。然而，鉴于政府的支持率较低，保留必要的 233 个席位来维持多数席位似乎越来越遥不可及。

;
;;
;;人们聚集在一起周二在东京聆听候选人的巡回演讲。图片来源：共同社;
;
;

;保守派《读卖新闻》的一项调查显示，在单议席选区的 266 名候选人中，只有 100 人的职位似乎稳固。大约 120 场竞选势均力敌，另外 40 名候选人面临重大挑战。

;

;天普大学东京校区的政治学家村上弘美 (Hiromi Murakami) 认为，公众的不满源于石破茂不一致的领导。

;< “在领导人选举之前，他完全坚定了要对涉及金融丑闻的党员采取的措施，但在当选后不久他就收回了立场，”她告诉《亚洲周刊》。

;

;“人们觉得他没有勇敢地面对那些政客、派别，现在不能相信他会做他所说的事情……选民感到失望。”

;< div>;;
;;日本执政党自民党高市早苗。图片来源：共同社;
;;

;由于竞争激烈的选区众多，村上预测自民党将“非常接近”地赢得简单多数席位。她还警告说，公明党可能会转而效忠另一个政党，从而有可能使自民党边缘化。

;

;“党内保守派中有很多成员感到沮丧，”她说。

;

;“该党保守派中有很多成员感到沮丧。” >;

;根据纳吉的说法，这个由鹰派高市早苗领导的派系（石破在党内领导地位上被击败）可能已经做好了迎接挑战的准备。

;

;“石破没有给人留下好印象，”他说。 “他没有经验，他不是党内的团队合作者，他的背后没有传统派系。这使他变得软弱和脆弱，如果他无法在任何政策提案上取得进展，那么他就没有政治资本继续担任总理。

;

;“我没有看到他取得任何成就，他可能会在短短六个月内离开，这为 Takaichi 打开了大门。”Nagy 补充道。

; Sat, 19 Oct 2024 09:50:02 +0800 In US vs Chinese soft power, guess how children are voting?https://www.scmp.com/opinion/china-opinion/article/3281354/us-vs-chinese-soft-power-guess-how-children-are-voting?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2024.10.19 09:30;
;;
;;2020年，孩子们在上海迪士尼度假区聊天。 照片：路透社 ;
;

;我十几岁的侄子的手指在他的语言引擎前飞驰，他勇敢地尝试用普通话给我提供一步一步的魔方教程，但在第三或第四个ranhou（ “然后”），他的声音逐渐减弱。他的弟弟再也听不下去了，脱口而出，“你为什么不能用英语告诉她？”

;

;他不能，他轻轻地解释道，我忍住笑声，因为阿姨“不太懂英语”。

;

;这就是可怜的老我了，我自封为中国传统的守护者，一直强调对家里的孩子说普通话，从不说英语。希望他们不会失去汉语作为第一语言，从而轻松进入文化世界。然而，我的事业有时感觉像是一个失败的事业。

;

;对于男孩和他们这一代的许多其他人来说，日托是生活中的一个事实。当孩子们用英语（多种族新加坡的通用语言）进行社交时，只要他们能够说句子，英语很快就会成为他们感到宾至如归的语言，并且他们会在观看 YouTube、Netflix 和电视时使用英语。实际上已经到家了。一旦他们中的一些人陷入了学龄前品牌的幼儿节目和玩具公司的动画系列的英语兔子洞，他们成为迪士尼爱好者、漫威超级英雄崇拜者、庆祝万圣节的粉丝似乎只是时间问题

;

;因此，即使在像我这样传统上讲粤语和普通话的家庭中，孩子们自己和父母也坚持使用英语。汉语逐渐退居幕后，母语不如祖母语；据说，对包括我在内的老年人来说，如果他们能把视线从《内裤队长》、《幻影忍者》、《少年谢尔顿》或通过电视、平板电脑或手机在 Netflix 上沉迷的任何内容上移开，那就是礼貌。

;

;成年人试图用大量的华语内容进行干预，从中国动画到配音为普通话的日本卡通。不过，与中国动画相比，孩子们更喜欢日本动画，并且已经研究出如何以英语流式传输动画系列。

;
;;
;;一个女孩站起来2015 年，在香港时代广场与乐高星球大战人物近距离接触。一旦一些孩子接触了学前品牌和玩具公司的英语内容，他们往往会很快成为美国流行文化的粉丝。照片：Dickson Lee;
;
;

;我想知道在年轻一代中，中国的软实力是否有很大机会对抗美国的文化产业综合体。

;

;在我和我的兄弟们成长的一代人之前，美国流行文化还没有那么普遍。当然，我们熟悉《芝麻街》、《史酷比》、《超人》等。但我们的玩伴很可能穿着超级英雄的斗篷和浴巾，我们假装是剑客和剑女飘逸的长袍，当我们坐在转椅和挥舞的尺子上飘过客厅时，我们可以重新捕捉到中年风格。 -在睡前播出的小屏幕武侠小说中瞥见了空中决斗。

;

;20世纪80年代，中国刚刚揭开竹帘，并不是我们即将前往的国家。但是，以武侠流派形式（在印刷品、银幕和歌曲中）唤起的奇幻历史中央王国是世界各地许多华语人民的集体梦想世界。

;

;我的父亲担心我的兄弟们如果我们在幼儿园时背童话故事，我就没有足够的英语接触机会来掌握它。按照他的逻辑，如果中国的学生必须熟记四书五经才能了解汉语的来龙去脉，那么我们作为外语学生至少可以背诵十几本英语故事书。

;
;;
;;2018年香港文化博物馆金庸馆展出的武侠小说电视剧改编作品。摄影：Nora Tam;
;
;

;虽然中国人几乎就在我们喝的水中，但我父母也不认为我们会通过渗透来吸收它。相反，父亲向我们讲述了笨手笨脚的佛教朝圣者三藏和他的降妖弟子孙悟空、猪八戒和沙僧的冒险经历，即兴表演了我们的漫画套装，这是四大金刚中最适合儿童的漫画。中国小说。

;

;我母亲给我们读了根据中国哲学教义改编的寓言故事，其中包括老人敢于移山的故事，他相信他的子孙将完成他所开创的事业；一个傻瓜因为忘记了自己的脚尺寸而没有亲自去买鞋的寓言；不认识三加四的猴子的故事与四加三相同。

;

;这最后一个来自道家哲学家庄子，仍然是个人的试金石：提醒不要被抓住错误地追求数字。但我不确定这些故事是否适合今天沉迷于 Netflix 的孩子们。

;

;我的小弟弟，两个男孩的父亲，对他们学习语言和文化持乐观态度。他认为，只要他们掌握了基本的中文，他们的根源就永远等待被发现。

;
;;
;;广告9 月 3 日，根据《西游记》改编的电子游戏《黑神话：悟空》在北京首都国际机场亮相。图片：彭博社;
;
;

;现在，我从孩子们对农历新年的传统食物充满热情，尤其是鱼沙拉，它起源于我祖父母的家乡中国南部珠江三角洲的日常菜肴，但后来演变为新加坡的节日必备品。年复一年，我的母亲坚持手工切割色彩缤纷的萝卜、胡萝卜、芜菁等做沙拉，以保留所有这些蔬菜的脆度和汁液，尽管随着年龄的增长，这种劳累的工作变得越来越困难.

;

;今年，我的侄子过来让事情变得容易一些，在大家庭聚集在一起并将沙拉扔到一个大盘子上之前，他悄悄地在厨房里帮助我和我的母亲 - 挥舞着一堆沙拉用筷子，将糖搅拌成酸橙汁，然后加入鱼，花生油，然后一步一步地加入其他配料，这是我已故祖母传下来的。

;“在我们的生活中，尤其是在香港这个非常繁忙的城市，停下来真正体验和享受生活在当下是一件非常罕见的事情，这就是当你赶上浪潮时会发生的事情，”他说。 “你必须忘记之前和之后。”

;

;但是詹姆斯和其他冲浪者一样，最近在当地的海滩感到不受欢迎，几十年来，该海滩一直被视为该市的顶级运动目的地。< /p>;

;“救生员对冲浪者和尝试冲浪的人的干扰有所增加，”他说。 “对于我们冲浪者来说，最令人困惑的是我们不知道为什么。我们还没有真正得到有关此事的澄清或信息。”

;

;虽然政府从未允许在公共海滩冲浪，称这有危及游泳者的风险，但该禁令从未得到严格执行。大浪湾至少有三家商店几十年来一直在出租冲浪板，冲浪者长期以来一直是大浪海滩上常见的景象。

;

;“我认为人们必须接受更多有关这些运动的教育，而不是全部禁止，”曾说。< /p>;

;;

;詹姆斯还指出，当地的冲浪季节很短，这是当局在管理这项运动时可以考虑的另一个因素。

;“Technology is at the centre of what we do and what we seek to do,” the veteran envoy said. “Supply-chain support integration between the United States and Japan is essential.”

;
;
;

;Tokyo is a global leader in semiconductor equipment manufacturing and shares many of Washington's concerns about Beijing, which controls about 60 per cent of critical minerals production worldwide.

;

;Japan has joined the US in imposing export controls on China, taking up broader efforts to cut off the world's second-largest economy from a technology supply chain that the allies fear could bolster the People's Liberation Army.

;

;The US and Japan earlier this week closed ranks with South Korea on another matter of mutual concern: Beijing's claims over most of the South China Sea.

;

;Campbell, meeting with his Japanese and South Korean counterparts in Seoul on Wednesday, joined a statement of opposition to “unlawful maritime claims in the South China Sea” – an apparent reference to China.

;

;Last year, the US, Japan and South Korea expanded security ties at an unprecedented summit in Camp David, Maryland. The three have steadily increased joint military drills in response to military actions by China and North Korea in the Indo-Pacific.

;

;Beijing has repeatedly criticised Washington's coalition building, describing it as “bloc confrontation” and arguing it destabilises regional peace.

;

;China-Japan relations have long been strained over the island nation's wartime crimes against civilians on the mainland committed between 1937 and 1945 as well as the two countries' competing sovereignty claims over the East China Sea.

;

;The presidential race between and comes at a time of rising geopolitical tensions on multiple fronts. In the sixth report of an , Shi Jiangtao reports on how the US election outcome could impact the future of Taiwan.

;

;With the race for the White House deadlocked less than a month before the election, Beijing has continued to refrain from signalling a preference for Vice-President Kamala Harris or former president Donald Trump to be the next US leader, or any other election-related questions.

;

;But regardless of who wins the election, diplomatic analysts agree that Taiwan will remain the biggest thorn in bilateral ties and one of the most dangerous flashpoints in a possible conflict between Washington and Beijing.

;

;They warn of the risks of exacerbating cross-strait tensions amid heightened uncertainty in the next four years and a challenge for the next president to strike the right balance between deterrence and reassurance, which US President Joe Biden has skilfully navigated.

;

;While the Democratic and Republican nominees have sparred fiercely on almost everything from the economy, abortion, to climate and Ukraine, there has been a growing bipartisan consensus in Washington on the need to get tougher on China and bolster Taiwan's defence capabilities.

;

;Zhiqun Zhu, a professor of international relations and director of the China Institute at Bucknell University in Pennsylvania, said Beijing may not have a preference for Harris or Trump, as far as Taiwan is concerned.

;

;“The two will bring about different types and levels of challenges for Beijing with their China and Taiwan policies,” he said. “Taiwan will remain the thorniest and most dangerous issue between the United States and China, no matter who occupies the White House next year.”

;

;Beijing regards Taiwan as part of China, to be reunited by force if necessary 。 The US, like most countries, does not recognise the island as independent, but is opposed to any attempt to reunify the island by force and has remained Taiwan's staunchest backer and top arms supplier.

;

;The security situation in the Taiwan Strait has continued to deteriorate this year, as Beijing has ramped up military, political and economic pressure against the island's independence-leaning new leader, William Lai Ching-te, who took office in May.

;

;On September 18, two days after Washington approved its 16th arms sale to Taiwan since Biden took office in 2021, Beijing unveiled fresh sanctions on nine US defence firms over their involvement in the US$228 million deal.

;

;On the same day, citing Lai's “stubborn adherence” to a pro-independence stance, Beijing also announced the removal of tariff exemptions on 34 imports from the island, including vegetables, fruit and seafood, on top of a similar measure in May targeting more than 130 Taiwanese goods.

;

;Shi Yinhong, professor of international relations at Beijing-based Renmin University of China, said the deterioration in the cross-strait relations was worrying, especially considering signs of an accelerating arms race between China and the US towards a potential conflict.

;

;“It is clear the situation in the Taiwan Strait has become increasingly treacherous,” he said, despite some progress on the resumption of the military-to-military communication between Beijing and Washington since Biden met Chinese President Xi Jinping in San Francisco in November last year.

;

;“To prevent China from dominating the situation around Taiwan and to prevent China from achieving cross-strait reunification, the US, whether it was under Trump's presidency or during Biden's tenure, has made significant and extensive efforts to bolster military support for Taiwan and prepare for a war with China over Taiwan,” he said. “I doubt there will be any major shift under a Harris or Trump administration.

;

;“In this sense, on the Taiwan issue, there is simply not much difference between the two candidates, except that Trump may have much less predictability than Harris, which would obviously be more detrimental to the situation in the Taiwan Strait.”

;

;Harris, who had limited foreign policy experience before she became vice-president three years ago, has made relatively few public pronouncements on China so far.

;

;In an interview with 60 Minutes on CBS earlier this month, Harris said the US “should not seek conflict”, but instead protect American business interests. She did not say whether the US would use military force to support Taiwan.

;

;“I'm not going to get into hypotheticals,” Harris said. “But listen, we need to make sure that we maintain a one-China policy, but that includes supporting Taiwan's ability to defend itself, including what we need to do to ensure the freedom of the Taiwan Strait.”

;

;According to Sourabh Gupta, a senior policy specialist with the Institute for China-America Studies in Washington, the broad trend lines of a Harris presidency on Taiwan policy are likely to closely follow those of the Biden administration.

;

;“For the most part, the Biden team operated within the confines of the US one-China policy … and has been consistent in its messaging and practices since the November 2022 G20 summit in Bali,” he said.

;

;He noted some “instability” in the interpretation of the one-China policy during the first 18 months of the administration, when Biden vowed four times to defend Taiwan in the event of an armed attack by mainland China.

;
;
;

;Although each time the White House was quick to clarify the US policy on Taiwan – known as “strategic ambiguity” – Chinese officials and many China watchers believed those “gaffes” underlined the Biden administration's push towards strategic clarity on the Taiwan issue.

;

;In the meantime, however, the Biden White House has repeatedly reassured Beijing at every presidential and senior-level meeting that the US does not support “Taiwan independence”, does not support “two Chinas” or “one China, one Taiwan”, and does not seek to use the Taiwan question as a tool to contain China, according to Gupta.

;

;“I do not expect the Harris team to depart substantially from this stance,” he added.

;

;Zhu also said Harris was likely to continue Biden's approach towards Taiwan, such as providing weapons and military aid to Taiwan, “internationalising the Taiwan issue”, and opposing unilateral change of the status quo.

;

;“A Harris administration is unlikely to help improve cross-strait relations, and cross-strait relations will remain deadlocked and dangerous,” he said.

;

;By contrast, the return of Trump and his isolationist approach to the White House would almost certainly introduce “a dose of uncertainty” into the Taiwan Strait situation, according to Zhu.

;

;“Trump probably does not care much about Taiwan from his transactional perspective, but he is likely to be surrounded by avid China hawks who may wish to see some crises in the Taiwan Strait as part of their ongoing efforts to counter China,” he said. “Trump's approach to Taiwan and the situation in the Taiwan Strait all depends on to what extent Trump's policy will be shaped by the hawks around him and in Congress.”

;
;;
;;The future of Washington's relations with Taipei may largely be determined by the foreign and defence policy credentials of the next US president. Photo: AFP via Getty Images/TNS;
;
;

;During his first term, Trump adopted a confrontational approach on China that marked the end of America's engagement policy towards Beijing since former president Richard Nixon , and strengthened diplomatic and military support for Taiwan.

;

;Trump has so far dodged the contentious question about whether Washington should defend Taiwan, claiming in an interview with Time magazine earlier this year that he would not want to “reveal my card” or “give away any negotiating abilities”.

;

;Although Trump showed in his first term that he wants to relinquish at least part of the US' global leadership to focus on domestic affairs, he has also made it clear that opposition to China forms a key part of his foreign policy agenda, according to Benoit Hardy-Chartrand, an international affairs expert at Temple University Japan in Tokyo.

;

;“Given the interviews he has given and his speeches on the campaign trail, there's no indication that a second Trump administration would be much different on that front,” he said.

;

;In an interview with Bloomberg Businessweek in July, Trump said “Taiwan should pay us for defence” and complained that the island had taken “almost 100 per cent” of the semiconductor industry from the US.

;

;Further, Trump's “strong mercantilist grievances” against Taiwan could push America's strategic ambiguity posture on Taiwan, a strategy not to explicitly spell out whether and to what extent, the US military will intervene in a war across the Taiwan Strait, to “one of strategic clarity”, Gupta added.

;
;
;

; “至少，特朗普政府领导下的台湾政策将比哈里斯政府领导下更加严厉的反华政策。 At worst, the bottom could fall out if the Trump team determinedly moves forward to significantly deepen its military-military ties with Taipei, such as via port calls, joint patrols, joint and combined exercises, or an enduring troop presence on the island that goes beyond the mere skeletal.”

;

;Yun Sun, director of the China programme and co-director of the East Asia programme at the Stimson Centre in Washington, warned that Beijing may need to be on alert as both Harris and Trump were expected to lend strong support to Taiwan.

;

;“That is the consistency of US policy toward Taiwan. Neither is going to work in favour of China's desired unification,” she said.

;

;“I am not worried about Harris' lack of experience on this particular issue.美国对台政策有其内在有效性、正当性和国会支持。 It is not a policy that can be significantly altered,” she said.

;

;Taiwan always poses greater risks for potential conflict than other issues such as North Korea or the South China Sea, given the sensitivity of the Taiwan issue and the current state of cross-strait relations, according to Sun.

;

;Takashi Hosoda, an assistant professor at the Institute of Intelligence Studies at the University of Defence in the Czech Republic, said that regardless of the outcome of the US election, tensions over Taiwan were unlikely to ease because of the intensifying US-China rivalry.

;

;Aside from internal US political factors favouring a hardline approach towards China to secure American's supremacy in an increasingly chaotic and uncertain world, Beijing and Washington had entered a vicious “competitive spiral” in the name of military deterrence, he said.

;

;“An increasing number of indications of the possibility of a Taiwan crisis within the US and its like-minded allies means … an increasing perception of the crisis for the US and her partners about the material balance against China becoming more China-dominant,” he said.

;

;“At the same time, there has been an increase in attempts by both the US and China to use the 'sense of crisis' to strengthen their defence posture further, sell arms, and influence the cognitive domain of the other.”

;

;Compared to Biden's “measured and balanced” handling of the Taiwan issue, it would be hard for his successor to strike the right balance between deterrence and reassurance, considering Trump's track record and Harris' relative lack of experience on China, according to Gupta.

;

;“It is not a given that a Harris administration will be as successful or lucky,” he said, adding that much would depend on the extent of senior officials' continuity within her team.

;

;“Besides, as a first-term president with light foreign and defence policy credentials, her disposition towards China – and especially during a Taiwan Strait flare-up – is likely to be harder-line than would ordinarily be the case, so as to cover her political flanks,” he said.

;

;“All said, security in the Taiwan Strait will be at greater risk over the next four years compared to the past four. And I haven't even got to Donald Trump and many of his hardline and Sinophobic Republicans appointees.”

;

;Shi, from the Renmin University, said that while it was worrisome to see extensive war preparations by both China and the US over a possible contingency for Taiwan, it was also important to remember that the cross-strait situation had been tumultuous over the years.

;

;“The situation in the Taiwan Strait has always been dangerous, so only God knows whether there will be a war there between China and the US,” he said.

;

;But thanks to the long-simmering tensions, both Chinese and American militaries and their frontline troops had had plenty of experience in dealing with each other and preventing accidental conflicts, Shi said.

;

;“In addition, China and the US have markedly strengthened their efforts to prevent military conflicts in the past year.”
